territory.notes: French expeditions in the Niger began in the late 19th century and led to the establishment of a French “Middle Niger Circle” north of Niamey in 1898. A major French military campaign to assert military control over the region began in 1899. Immediately thereafter, several French administrative and military jurisdictions were established, but their precise jurisdictions and relationships to one another are not clear from the sources consulted. These French jurisdictions included: the “Cercle du Djerma,” established in western Niger on October 11, 1900; the French Third Military Territory for the Central Sudan, established on December 20, 1900, and provisionally headquartered north of Niamey in the same town as the Cercle du Djerma; and the Military Territory of Zinder, established on January 1, 1901, with headquarters in Zinder (eastern/southern Niger). These jurisdictions may have been part of a single French military territory by as early as 1903, as sources refer to the headquarters of “the military territory” moving back and forth between Niamey and Zinder on several occasions beginning that year. The “Territoire Militaire du Niger” (Military Territory of the Niger) was established on June 22, 1910, and appears to have consolidated these prior French administrative and military jurisdictions in the region. The Colony of the Niger was established July 1, 1922. On August 22, 1945, it became a French Overseas Territory, which afforded greater forms of self-governance. The colony became the independent Republic of Niger on August 3, 1960.
